Description: A massive girdle: of bright-green glazed steatite short and standard cylinder beads strung closely together in nine separate rows. Each of the eight double-waisted bone spacer-beads is pierced by three holes.
Curator's comments: Found over the knees of a male corpse. Brunton identifies the bone spacer-beads as being made of shell. This is the only occurrence of spacers before the Early Dynastic Period. The beads were actually found over the knees of a male: such bead girdles were typically male ornaments during the Badarian period. Bibliography: G. Brunton, ‘Mostagedda and the Tasian Culture’ (London, 1937), 37, 51, 52, 60, 61; pl. XXIII, 4; Grave register, pl. VIII; Bead corpus, pl. XXXIX, 95C4; 'Ancient Egypt' (London, 1934), 70, fig. 1; The British Museum, 'Jewellery through 7000 years' [exhibition catalogue] (London, 1976), no. 3.
Bibliographic references: Andrews 1981 / Catalogue of Egyptian Antiquities. Jewellery I (41)
